Forge Friday Roundup - August 24, 2018
      

    
  
      
      
          
    
        
    
  



  

        
                                      Forge Friday Roundup - August 24, 2018
          
                                                        
      
                      
  
  
  
    

  
  
    


Image via Pexels/Pixabay


  









  
    August 24, 2018  

In today’s Roundup: bot networks inflame vaccine “debate”; nutrition research comes in for critical scrutiny; crowdsourcing statistical analysis; polygenic risk scores; alphabetical authorship and academic obscurity; health systems turn toward the built environment; AI doesn't have to be used for ill; right to try dissected; and much more.

Communications and Digital Society
Deeply disturbing findings published in the American Journal of Public Health about Russian bot networks acting to inflame the vaccine “debate” have been receiving widespread media coverage. The activity, which included both pro- and anti-vaccine stances, may have been primarily intended to amplify confusion and sow discord rather than favor a particular viewpoint.

Facebook announces that it has spotted and shut down additional covert online influence campaigns ahead of the U.S. midterm elections. Iran and Russia are implicated.

Fast Company reports on a purge of Facebook pages devoted to pseudoscience and “alternative health,” but notes that the enormously popular and profitable website Goop has remained untouched, despite being the focus of concentrated criticism related to dubious health products and claims. What remains unclear is what criteria the content platform is applying when deciding to remove content.

AI, Statistics, and Data Science
Crowdsourcing for statistical analysis? In a preprint available from PsyArXiv, Silberzahn and colleagues show how choice of analytical methods and variations in covariate selection impact results.

“We can always do better than pretending we know nothing about a parameter, even when we know nothing in particular about a parameter.” At the blog Elements of Evolutionary Anthropology, a look at why “if priors did not exist, you would have to invent them.” (H/T @F2Harrell)

NPR looks at how Stanford researchers go about teaching self-driving cars to drive. Turns out that human unpredictability tends to be a major source of discomfiture for robot vehicles.

“A coordinated effort by civil society, politics, business, and academia will help to identify and pursue the best strategies to make AI a force for good and unlock its potential to foster human flourishing while respecting human dignity.” A perspective article in Science by Taddeo and Floridi reminds readers of the vast potential that AI represents for human benefit.

Social Determinants of Health
“The stress of living with violence and trauma, racial segregation, and unstable living conditions leads to something researchers call ‘the neighborhood effect.’" A fascinating article at NPR’s health-focused Shots blog touches on the social determinants of health and looks at why healthcare systems are starting to take notice of housing and environmental factors as a focus for preventive care measures.

For some time now, there has been growing concern that an excessive focus on making playgrounds safe has rendered them boring, discouraging kids from active play and thereby paradoxically exposing them to different kinds of health and developmental harms. Citylab takes a look at the movement to restore challenge and risk to kids’ play spaces and the legal and cultural headwinds it faces.

Clinical Research and Public Health


Image credit: Magda Ehlers (via Pexels)




Based on the ACC 2015 Professional Life Survey, the AHA reports that 27% of cardiologists suffer burnout primarily from excessive administrative requirements.

Bad news for Dr. Zaius: alphabetical authorship order may boost the academic profile of researchers lucky enough to have last names that put them higher up the authorship list.

At the New York Times’ Upshot blog, Aaron Carroll explains the benefits and challenges of comparative effectiveness trials.

The BBC reports that the UK House of Commons' Science and Technology Committee is strongly in favor of vaping as a means to help smokers quit. But the National Institute for Health Care and Excellence points to a lack of authoritative research on the effects of vaping.

In an article published in the New England Journal of Medicine, Ami Bhatt explores the future of new biosensors such as the ingestible micro-bioelectronic device designed by Mimee and colleagues.

In a viewpoint article in JAMA, John Ioannidis takes on the parlous state of epidemiologic research in nutrition.

A detailed post by Roxland and Hurley at PRIM&R’s blog dissects the recently enacted federal “right-to-try” law and explores some of its implications.

In NPJ Digital Medicine: digital phenotypes, real-world evidence, and data-driven practice for the field of psychiatry. (H/T @EricTopol)

STAT News report that Canadian researchers have completed a very early-stage study that, if successful, could hold the key to transforming different blood types into Type O blood. Their technique revolves around a recently discovered enzyme found in bacteria residing in the human gut.

A European study reports on the development of polygenic risk scores for coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, type 2 diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and breast cancer.




  
    Author  

  
    

      


  
    
              
                                Forge Health Data Science Squadron
                            
      
      
        The Health Data Science Squadron is Duke Forge's communications team.
